reviewText: These are definitely "B" movies. That does not make them bad at all. Pretty corny but lots of fun and pretty well done. You can, besides being entertained, get a feeling for the times (1956) pertaining to Rock and Roll's beginnings. For want of a better expression, Rock and Roll was "deciding" what it was going to sound like. Pop music was changing. The bands were getting smaller. the sounds were changing from orchestras to combos... Jazz, Rhythm and Blues, Latino, novelty and vocal groups were all about to collide to form sounds like no one had heard before. The WW2 generation was no longer the focus. The new generation of kids coming of age was. New, brash inventions upon the jitterbug and the music the kids danced to was also coming of age.These movies show off the new (In 1956) sound, it's advocates, detractors and the kids. You see performances by The Platters, Little Richard, Bill Haley and some other excellent, but lesser known acts... And dancing! These were some of the "Founding Fathers" of Rock and Roll. The rest is history but these are views to the revolution.

reviewText: Two stars because it is historic having early rock and rollers on camera. Also is a double feature. It is a sad story line. The movies were made just to make a quick buck, which it did. Even though you get two movies, the price is still too high. This should sell for about 6 or 7 bucks max. Too much money for what you get. If the money doesn't matter, and your a fan of the comets, then go ahead and get.

reviewText: This two disc set rates 5 stars for the music and choreography.  The highlight of the set is the "Rip It Up" dance number from Don't Knock The Rock.  The dancing in this number is absolutely amazing.  I watched this sequence about 5 times over two days.The second best moment is the "See You Later Alligator" sequence from Rock Around the Clock.  Again, great song and great choreography.All in all, a great set that didn't disappoint me.

reviewText: This double-feature DVD showcases the first rock-'n' roll musical, "Rock Around the Clock," and its sequel, "Don't Knock the Rock.""Rock Around the Clock" (1956) can be enjoyed again and again as a lightweight B-musical. It features faithful depictions of hit records (in fact, they ARE the hit records, persuasively lip-synched by the performers), and the small-town-band-hits-the-big-time plotline is pleasantly familiar. Bill Haley and His Comets are not called upon to act (Haley has only a few lines of dialogue), but they run through many of their hits: "Rock Around the Clock," "See You Later, Alligator," "R-O-C-K," "Rock A-Beatin' Boogie," and more. (Haley's irrepressible sidemen Rudy Pompilli and Al Rex do some playful shtick during the "Rudy's Rock" production number.) The Platters deliver two of their greats, "Only You" and "The Great Pretender." Freddie Bell and the Bell Boys offer spirited high-school-band arrangements, featuring vocals by the enthusiastic Ernie Maresca, and Tony Martinez's cha-cha band adds some Latin rhythms. Pioneer rock deejay Alan Freed appears as himself, and Johnny Johnston, Henry Slate, Alix Talton, Lisa Gaye, and John Archer acquit themselves nicely in the story sections. This vehicle is so sturdy that the producer remade it almost scene for scene as "Twist Around the Clock" -- no contest, the original is far superior. Great fun, especially if you like the original records."Don't Knock the Rock" (1957) is another B-movie quickie, but this time a heavy-handed plot threatens to overwhelm the music. The stuffy town fathers crusade against the scourge of rock-'n'-roll, leaving Alan Dale (miscast as the romantic lead) and Alan Freed to champion the cause and prove the elders wrong. Ignore the plot and listen to the music. Haley's band is actually overshadowed this time, by Little Richard and especially by The Treniers (the energetic "Rocking on Sunday Night" is probably the best number in the show).Between these two features you have an excellent sampling of mid-1950s rock, as demonstrated by its originators. Highly recommended for B-musical and vintage-rock fans.
summary: 4 stars for "Clock," 2 stars for "Knock." Some excellent music from the dawn of rock

reviewText: This is a review for the double DVD set of ROCK AROUND THE CLOCK(1956) and DON'T KNOCK THE ROCK (1957).  Both pictures were quicklymade so as to take advantage of what many thought to be a fleetingmusical fad, Rock 'n Roll.But the best thing about these films now is they sort of preservethe first flush of enthusiasm brought to the teen public bythat big beat hybryd, rock 'n roll.IN ROCK AROUND THE CLOCK the real rock/ pop stars  are Bill Haley andthe Comets and  the Platters although  Freddie Bell and the Bell Boysprobably sold some platters but they look more like a lounge act to me.But Alan Freed's on hand to introduce the Haleymen doing the all timeclassic, Rock Around the Clock along with a couple of more rockers.The story concerns a couple of disillusioned big band vets who stumbleacross this new type of popular music along with bands and dancerswho are really able to get people out on the floor, a sight for soreeyes according to everyone.  They all go to the big town for a shot atthe big time which, after a few plot complications, happens to be a networkTV Coast to Coast Rock 'n Roll Jamboree hosted by Alan Freed.In DON'T KNOCK THE ROCK local parents are worried that Rock 'n Roll'sinfluence will help turn their teens into juvenile deliquents but with thehelp of Alan Freed and singer Arnie Haines, played by Alan Dale, a liverock 'n roll show proves otherwise.DON'T KNOCK THE ROCK has more music by Bill Haley and the Comets, along withThe Treniers, performances by "Arnie Haynes" as played by Alan Daleand best of all, Little Richard and his band for two numbers.The truth be told, it looks like a lot of these acts if not all of themare lip synching, but I won't tell if you won't pantomime the news toanyone else.Anyway both films are a lot of fun and the music is for the most part, adelight.  Sure, this set is over fifty years old but it's really enjoyableto watch the beginings of a new style of entertainment get started andenjoyed.Four Stars.
